item.title: Assignment 2: option to reset your database table (Web Technology 2015)
item.description: Dear all, Most of you have by now a large number of test values in your table, both from testing Assignment 1 and Assignment 2. Several of you requested a service to reset your table to the original values. This has been implemented (thanks Jelmer!) and is now deployed after I updated the server this morning. I just have performed a reset on my own key�d1f21b14�using: http://wt.ops.few.vu.nl/api/d1f21b14/reset You can do the same if you would like to start from fresh with your original table values, by replacing the key with your own key. Of course this is entirely optional, the actual values in your table will in no way influence the grading. Success with finishing Assignment 2

item.title: Resit (Pervasive Computing (2014-2015)_120)
item.description: The resit is on Febr 10th, 18:30-21:15 in WN-KC137. If you failed the exam, as soon as the grades are registered� in vu_net (friday 16 Jan) you can register for the resit. The deadline is 2 weeks until the exam.

item.title: Assignment 2: getting started tips (Web Technology 2015)
item.description:
Dear all, During this morning's lab A group session, some students had trouble getting started with assignment 2.�Here are a few tips for all of you (mostly repeating tips given during the lectures):
Start the lab session with Assignment 2, as it continues the client-side work you did in lab 2 last week, and do the server-side lab questions only if you have made a good start with Assignment 2. Have a look at the recipes�shown in the lecture, see slides 29-32 of lecture 4 (course link attached) Make sure you have seen the ajax in jquery example referred to in slide 29! (http://www.w3schools.com/jquery/ajax_ajax.asp) Make sure you have a working example from the jquery tutorial and start making changes from there, line by line Now where your browser's console is and how to use it to log useful information
Good luck!

item.title: Preparation & reading material Lecture 7 & 8 available (Web Technology 2015)
item.description: Dear all, The preparation material for lecture 7 (Search) and 8 (Accessibility) is now available. Both lectures will be given by Dr. de Boer.

item.title: Course Evaluations (Pervasive Computing (2014-2015)_120)
item.description: Please be so kind to fill in the course evaluation form in vu_net. Your opinion is very valuable for us for two reasons. (1)� if you liked the course, then your positive thoughts will encourage us to continue teaching it, and most important (2) if you did not like it, then your suggestions and ideas will help us to improve this course for next year. The deadline is on January 13th. Thank you. Natalia Silvis

item.title: The exam solutions are on-line (Pervasive Computing (2014-2015)_120)
exams and failed socket assignments (Computer Networks (2014-2015)_120)
item.description:
Some of you asked about what to do if you failed the socket assignments. In principle, the idea was that you would be out of luck. However, to prevent you from having to wait for another year, what I will do for the next (resit) exam is add a question on sockets programming -- only for those who failed the assignments. The question will be fail/pass and not count for your overall grade (except that you *have* get a pass). Oh an FYI: I am still busy grading the exam.
Cheers, HJB

item.title: Web Technology starting (Web Technology 2015)
item.description:
Dear student, Welcome to the Web Technology course! The course starts Monday, with the first two lectures. The requires some preparation from your side:
Around 50 of you have not yet enrolled for a lab group. �If you have not done so already, please do as soon as possible! This allows us to decide how many lab groups we need!� Please make the first Lecture preparation questions (see attachement) before you come the first lectures.
Hope to see you all on Monday, Jacco van Ossenbruggen

item.title: Preliminary reader available (Web Technology 2015)
item.description:
Dear students, Some of you asked for course material so they could start preparing for the course during the Xmas break. I've now made a preliminary reader available so you can already get a first glimpse of what the course will be about.�I expect to add more material in the coming weeks and during the course. First two lectures start on Monday January 5Please make sure you have read the Reader's introduction and the material marked with Lecture 1 and Lecture 2 before you come the first lectures. For those of you who have not yet enrolled for a lab group, please do so! �This allows us to estimate how many lab groups we need!
Thanks, and best wishes, Jacco van Ossenbruggen

item.title: Project Presentations (Pervasive Computing (2014-2015)_120)
item.description: Dear all, This is our last week. During your last lab session you will proudly present your projects. The first 20 min you will all have time to build your robot or/and setup and prepare it for a demo. Thereafter, each group will have ca 10 min to present and demonstrate. The structure of your Powerpoint presentation should be similar to your final document.� You have to say what did you design, why is this a pervasive system, who will use it and how, describe the system (hardware and software), which safety and ethical issues did you investigate, how did it work in practice, what did you learn, etc.� The demo has to be simple, but working. It is good to make in advance a videoclip with your demo and send it to your TA so that we can build a folder in BB with all these nice results. This will be interesting for your colleagues but also for new students next year. Please mail also in advance your presentation to your TA. There is a folder in BB called Project, where you can find examples of project documents. Other info about the project deliverables can be found in the Course Guide. Good luck ! �Natalia Silvis

item.title: Excellence track assignment 2 deadline today (Computer Networks (2014-2015)_120)
item.description: Don't forget, the deadline for excellence track assignment 2 is today at 23:59! Don't hesitate to submit partial solutions, especially if you didn't manage to figure out the bonus questions.

item.title: Some tips for your project (Pervasive Computing (2014-2015)_120)
item.description:
1. In order to use your lab time efficiently, we recommend you to write down a plan for each session. You should know exactly what are you going to do at the beginning of each session. For example: Today we will test the camera in front of a traffic light, or we will recognize two simple notes A and C, etc. Bring this plan to lab class, and discuss it shortly together with your TA. You can include these plans in your final report and reflect on possible discrepancies between your "nice" plans and the "harsh" reality.�� 2. Before searching for solutions on Internet, take a look at the Classification recipes in BB where you can find ideas and almost ready-to-use solutions.
Good luck!

item.title: deadline first online test : 24/11 before the lecture (Computer Networks (2014-2015)_120)
item.description: It seems the deadline for the first test is not visible �for you(?!). Anyway, you should submit the test before the lecture on next week Monday. Strictly speaking: 24/11, 15:30 (but you have a few minutes grace). Do not miss the deadline. That would be very very bad. It is better to fail it than to not make it. You have more than enough time, so play it safe and submit a day early.

First session is Lab4, and second session is a Seminar where you will present your plans for the project.� (Note that group 1CS swaps these 2 sessions). The seminars take place in the following rooms: 1CS - tue 15:30 - WN-S624 2CS - thu 11:00-WN-S624 3 CS - thu 9:00 -WN-S664 4CS - fri 11:00 - WN-S648 5CS - thu 11:00-WN-P624 1IMM-LI - fri 9:00-WN-S624 2IMM-LI-CS fri 13:30-WN-S624 3IMM-LI fri 9:00� WN-S648 4IMM-LI fri 15:30 WN-S648 5IMM-LI thu 13:30 WN-S624 6IMM-LI thu 15:30 WN-S624 7IMM-LI thu 15:30 WN-S648 8IMM-LI fri 15:30 WN-S624 9IMM-LI fri 13:30 WN-S648

item.title: Excellence Track Assignment 2 (Computer Networks (2014-2015)_120)
item.description:
Assignment 2 of the excellence track is now available under course documents. The deadline is November 28th. Make sure to start on time, as it is significantly more difficult than the first assignment.
We are currently grading the first assignment, and expect to have the grades this week. Each of you will receive a personal document with some feedback. In general the assignment was well made, except for the second bonus question. Many of you did recover the image payload, but none of you found the text message which was steganographically hidden within the image. We will therefore be lenient in grading this question.

item.description: Due to a lot of confusion about the deadline for the sockets assignment. The deadline of the assignment is on Friday the 5th of December at midnight.

item.title: Lab Pervasive computing rules (Pervasive Computing (2014-2015)_120)
item.description: I would like to remind you that: 1.It is compulsory to attend the lab at least once a week. 2. At the beginning of each lab, you have to deliver the answers to preparatory exercises. 3.You are not allowed to join the lab beyond the timeslots planned for your group, unless there is a special reason, discussed in advance with the teacher and the TA.

item.title: Extra session for Lab1 on Monday 10 nov (Pervasive Computing (2014-2015)_120)
item.description: We have planned two extra lab sessions for students who want to finish Lab1. The grades will not be improved, but it is a good opportunity to practice, as Lab1 builds the basics for Lab3 and Lab4. The sessions are planned on Monday 10 nov: 11:00-12:45 in S353 15:30-17:00 in S329 If you intend to attend, you have to register by sending an email to Natalia Silvis.

item.title: Question hours (Computer Networks (2014-2015)_120)
item.description: Every week Arthur and I will be available at the vu to help you with questions. Arthur will be available on Mondays from 11:30 until 13:00 And I (Tim) will be available on Tuesdays from 12:00 until 13:00 Since both take place in the break, most of you should be able to come to us at R249 in the WN building. But keep in mind that the discussion board will be available and monitored by all of us as much as possible.

item.title: "resit" practical of Programming (Programming (2014-2015)_110)
item.description: Students that did not pass the practical of the course Programming, can do the "resit" of this practical in period 2. In order to be able to do the resit you have to 1- send en E-mail to Bram Rodenburg (brg600@student.vu.nl) in which you request to be added to the bb page of the course Programming in period 2; 2- enroll yourself in a group

item.title: Deadlines (Computer Networks (2014-2015)_120)
item.description: The deadlines - for the online tests will be announced in class (typically < 1 week in advance) - for the assignments are 2 weeks before the exam - for the excellence track will be announced in class when we discuss the assignments.

item.title: And we are live! (Computer Networks (2014-2015)_120)
item.description: Welcome to Computer Networks 2014-2015. This year, many things are different. Diffferent period, different book, different assignment (but similarly tough exam)!We will use BB as our main means of communication, and I will try to push all slides to the Course Documents> section as soon as I have them. Also make sure to check out David's video lectures:� � http://media.pearsoncmg.com/ph/streaming/esm/tanenbaum5e_videonotes/tanenbaum_videoNotes.html The videos may not be enough by themselves, but they will get you a long way. (There are also my old video lectures in Course Documents>, but these are for a different book.) Also make sure to use the discussion forum for all your questions related to the course material, assignments, and excellence track. Finally, during the course, I will make several online tests available via BB. More about this during the lectures. Good luck on computer networks this year -- and happy hacking!

item.description:
In response to all your assignments, we have here some general points of feedback: - Always submit your Mathematica files (.nb) (You can make a .zip of your .pdf/.docx and .nb files). - Don't include foto's of your flowchart, draw this using special programs (BB) or use Paint.� - During the practicum session of tomorrow, question 1a of assignment 3 will be explained (For the LI students of group 2 and 4, this will be done at 11:00).
Kind regards, All the TA's of Computational Thinking

item.title: Group 2 and 4 (Computational thinking (2014-2015)_110)

Because some students will want to attend, and Romy will arrive at 11:00, group 2 students risk going without help during the practicum. That is why tomorrow, all IMM students of group 2 and 4 will have their practicum in P447, and all LI students of 2 and 4 in P337. item.title: Question 6 (Computational thinking (2014-2015)_110)
item.description:
Dear students, For everyone who wants to submit question 6 today: you can submit this question by mailing it to your student assistent. Mail adresses can be found by Contact.
Good luck with finishing this assignment,� Romy

item.title: question 6 of assignment 3 (Computational thinking (2014-2015)_110)
item.description: Dear students, It seems that a lot of students have problems with question 6 of assignment 3. So here is some explanation what is expected from you. In 6a we ask you for all the steps that you need to look up a recipe in a list with recipes. Compare this with looking up something in Google, e.g., something about an iPhone. Name all the steps that you would take to look up the information about an iPhone. This means starting with typing the search key to displaying the output (=the search results). In 6b you are asked to put the steps, you named in 6a, into a flowchart. In 6c you are asked to show us that following those steps in 6a really works. This means look up a function (please do not write program codes) in Mathematica which makes that possible. You could use, e.g., the search keys "Find", "Search" in Mathematica to find a particular function to make that work. The questions 6d and 6e are clear I think. You may hand in question 6 of this assignment till tomorrow (20 Sept.) before 1.00 PM. Good luck, Aniel Bhulai

item.title: Confusion between comparisons and rum time complexity (Computational thinking (2014-2015)_110)
item.description: Dear students, There are some confusions between comparisons and rum time complexity due to a mistake in slide 19 of the search algorithms. I have just uploaded the correct version of the slide. Please, take note of it. I apologize for any inconvenience and the confusion this may have caused. In the next lecture I will come back to this. Aniel Bhulai

item.title: Middle element in binary search (Computational thinking (2014-2015)_110)
item.description: Just to remind you that the middle element in binary search can be found as follow:(n-1)/2, where n is the number of elements in the list. The result is rounded up (see also slide 12 of search algorithms).

item.title: Alternative download location for Mathematica (and instructions) (Computational thinking (2014-2015)_110)
item.description: An alternative location to download Mathematica is� http://www.nat.vu.nl/~ivo/MM Here you will find different versions of Mathematica and instructions to install mathematica.

item.description: The documents for 'Fraude regulation' and 'Code of conduct for computer and network use at the VU' are available in Web links in the menu.

item.title: Group enrollment (Computational thinking (2014-2015)_110)
item.description: Please enroll in a group if you want to participate in the practical sessions. When you are enrolled in a group you will find the location and the assistent's name for the practical sessions. The slides are available in the Course Documents. In the last slide of every topic you will find the homework. For this course you need the book Computational Thinking, 1st Edition by Bhulai (ISBN 9781784343903),�available in de VU bookstore (main building).

item.title: Schedule in VUnet (Introduction Computer Science (2014-2015)_110)
item.description: Hello everyone, Some students experience problems with their schedule in VUnet. We cannot resolve this problem for you. However, there are two alternatives to view your schedule. These are: Official website: rooster.vu.nl -> select group -> CS1Unofficial: vurooster.nl -> groups -> CS1� Please note that these website do not show your personal schedule, but the overall schedule of the program your following.� If you experience trouble with your schedule in VUnet, the best thing you can do is email the Educational Office.

item.title: Group overview (Introduction Computer Science (2014-2015)_110)
item.description: Hello everyone, Since it wasn't clear for everybody where you can find the working group you're placed in, there are three options to determine this: 1. To determine which working group you are placed in, click on the link below or go to 'Working Groups -> Overview of working groups'. 2. Another possibility is that you can also view your group in the left-hand side of the menu. You will see something like 'Group CS 1', meaning that you are placed in working group 1. 3. In VUnet you can find the group you're placed in by looking at your personal schedule. The group you you'll see on Blackboard corresponds with the groups on rooster.vu.nl . The email addresses of your working group tutor can be found under 'Contacts'. On the rooster.vu.nl website you can also see who your tutor is. We also placed this information under 'Course Information'. Please also check that the group in which you are registerd is the same group as in Blackboard. If you have any trouble regarding your group assignment or Blackboard, please contact me: b.p.m.rodenburg@vu.nl

item.title: Practical group enrollment (Programming (2014-2015)_110)
item.description: This evening at 19:00 o'clock the schedules for the practical groups will be announced. The enrollment for the practical groups will also be opened. You can check the schedules of the different practical groups under the tab 'Timetables'. In the same tab you can also enroll yourself into a practical group. There are five different practical groups available. For this week you will only have a practical for two hours (one session). The rest of the weeks this will be six hours (three sessions). Please note that group 1 has overlap with the group 02 from Intro CS on Monday. If you experience any trouble, please mail me at: b.p.m.rodenburg@vu.nl
